sen.j: 後花園天皇（ごはなぞのてんのう、応永26年6月18日 （1419年7月10日） - 文明2年12月27日 （1471年1月18日） 在位：正長元年7月28日（1428年9月7日） - 寛正5年7月19日（1464年8月21日））は、室町時代の第102代天皇である。
sen.e: Emperor Gohanazono (July 10th, 1419 - January 18th, 1471), his reign was September 7th, 1428 - August 21st, 1464, he was the hundred and second Emperor during the Muromachi period.
Emperor Gohanazono (July 10th, 1419 - January 18th, 1471), his reign was from September 7th, 1428 to August 21st, 1464, he was the hundred and second Emperor during the Muromachi period.
Emperor Gohanazono (July 10, 1419 - January 18, 1471), his reign was from September 7, 1428 to August 21, 1464, he was the hundred and second Emperor during the Muromachi period.

sen.j: 名を彦仁（ひこひと）という。
sen.e: His posthumous name was Hikototo.
His posthumous name was Hikototo.
His posthumous name was Hikohito.

sen.j: 伏見宮貞成親王（伏見宮家三代目、崇光天皇の孫、後崇光院）の第二皇子。
sen.e: He was Fushimi no Miya Prince Sadafusa's second Prince. (The third representative of the Fushimi no Miya Family, Emperor Suko's grandchild, Go-Suko in.)
sen.cmt: 伏見宮家三代目→the third representative of the Fushimi no Miya Family[定訳不明]
sen.e: He was Fushimi no Miya Prince Sadafusa's second Prince. (The third representative of the Fushimi no Miya Family, Emperor Suko's grandchild, Go-Suko in.)
He was Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadafusa's second Prince. (The third representative of the Fushiminomiya family, Emperor Suko's grandchild, Gosuko-in.)
sen.cmt: Family→familyFushimi no Miya Prince Sadafusa's→Imperial Prince Fushiminomiya Sadafusa's人名の表記を修正

sen.j: 母は庭田経有の娘、敷政門院・源幸子。
sen.e: His mother was Tsuneari NIWATA's daughter, Fuseimon in, MINAMOTO no Koshi.
His mother was Tsuneari NIWATA's daughter, Fuseimon in, MINAMOTO no Koshi.
His mother was Tsuneari NIWATA's daughter, Fuseimon in, MINAMOTO no Koshi.

sen.j: 持明院統の本家筋に当たる。
sen.e: This was the main family line of the Jimyo-in Imperial line.
sen.cmt: 持明院統→the Jimyo-in Imperial line[定訳不明, Jimyoin To]
sen.e: This was the main family line of the Jimyo-in Imperial line.
This was the main family line of the Jimyo-in Imperial line.

sen.j: 後に後小松天皇の猶子になった。
sen.e: Later on he was adopted by Emperor Go- Komatsu.
Later on he was adopted by Emperor Go- Komatsu.
Later on he was adopted by Emperor Gokomatsu.

sen.j: 先代の称光天皇は1422年以降、幾度か危篤状態に陥るなど病弱で皇子が無く、後小松上皇は大覚寺統の動きを牽制する必要があった。
sen.e: The late Emperor, Emperor Shoko was not well and became in critical situation since 1422, since he did not have any children the ex-Emperor Gokomatsu needed to restrain the movement of the Daikaku-ji Imperial line.
sen.cmt: 大覚寺統→the Daikaku-ji Imperial line[定訳不明, Daikaku-ji To]
sen.e: Emperor Shoko was not well and had been in critical condition since 1422, and because he did not have any children, the ex-Emperor Gokomatsuf felth the need to restrain the proggression of the Daikaku-ji Imperial line.
sen.cmt: removed "late," as "late" means "deceased" which is obviously not the case here as Emperor Shoko is described as being in critical condition. Revised for clarity
sen.e: Emperor Shoko was not well and had been in critical condition since 1422, and because he did not have any children, the Retired Emperor Gokomatsu felt the need to restrain the progression of the Daikaku-ji Imperial line.
sen.cmt: 人名の表記を修正スペルを修正

sen.j: 称光天皇が亡くなる前に、伏見宮家より猶子を迎えることとなった。
sen.e: It was decided to adopt a child From the Fushimi no Miya family before Emperor Shoko passed away.
It was decided to adopt a child From the Fushimi no Miya family before Emperor Shoko passed away.
It was decided to adopt a child from the Fushiminomiya family before Emperor Shoko passed away.
sen.cmt: 人名の表記を修正スペルを修正

sen.j: 1428年に称光天皇が危篤に陥ると後南朝勢力などが活動の気配を見せ、室町幕府6代将軍の足利義教は伏見御所にいた彦仁王を保護し、治天の君である後小松上皇に新帝指名を求める。
sen.e: In 1428 when Emperor Shoko was in the critical situation, the ex-Southern Dynasty started showing their active political movement, the 6th Shogun in the Muromachi shogunate, Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA protected Prince Hikohito in the Fushimi Imperial Palace, and demanded ex-Emperor Gokomatsu, Chiten no kimi (ex-emperor who take control of the politics by ruling the cloister government), to appoint new emperor.
sen.cmt: 治天の君→[定訳不明、院政において実権を握って政治に当たった上皇をさす]
sen.e: In 1428 when Emperor Shoko was in critical condition, the ex-Southern Dynasty began revealing their active political ambitions, the 6th Shogun in the Muromachi shogunate, Yoshimitsu ASHIKAGA protected Prince Hikohito in the Fushimi Imperial Palace, and demanded ex-Emperor Gokomatsu, Chiten no kimi (ex-emperor who is in control of politics by ruling the cloister government), to appoint a new emperor.

In 1428 when Emperor Shoko was in critical condition, the Second Southern Court began revealing their active political ambitions, the 6th Shogun in the Muromachi bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), Yoshinori ASHIKAGA protected Prince Hikohito in the Fushimi Imperial Palace, and demanded Retired Emperor Gokomatsu, Chiten no kimi (ex-emperor who is in control of politics by ruling the cloister government), to appoint a new emperor.
sen.cmt: スペース削除ex-Southern Dynasty→Second Southern Courtshogunate→bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) Yoshimitsu→Yoshinoriex-Emperor→Retired Emperor

sen.j: 称光が崩御し、親王宣下のないまま1429年12月27日に即位。
sen.e: After Emperor Shoko died, Emperor Gohanazono succeeded to the throne on December 27th, 1429 without having Shino senge. (to title Prince be Imperial order)
sen.cmt: 親王宣下→to title Prince by Imperial order[定訳不明]
sen.e: After Emperor Shoko died, Emperor Gohanazono succeeded to the throne on December 27th, 1429 without having Shino senge. (the title Prince by Imperial order)
After Emperor Shoko died, Emperor Gohanazono succeeded to the throne on December 27, 1429 without having Shino senge (the title Prince by Imperial order).
sen.cmt: 日付表記を修正ピリオドの位置移動

sen.j: 後小松上皇が1433年まで院政を敷いた。
sen.e: Emperor Gokomatsu ruled the cloister government until 1433.
Emperor Gokomatsu ruled the cloister government until 1433.
Emperor Gokomatsu ruled the cloister government until 1433.

sen.j: それ以後は、30年余り親政を行い、この間、各地で土一揆が起こり、永享の乱や嘉吉の乱などでは、治罰綸旨を発するなど政治的役割も行った。
sen.e: Since then the Emperor ruled the direct government, during his reign when there were peasant's uprising incidents in many places, he acted the political role by issuing Jibatsu Rinji to regulate the incident in the Eikyo Disturbance and the Kakitsu Disturbance.
sen.cmt: 永享の乱や嘉吉の乱→the Eikyo Disturbance, the Kakitsu Disturbance[定訳不明] 治罰綸旨→Jibatsu Rinji[治罰は、取り締まり罰すること。綸旨は、みことのり]
sen.e: Since then the Emperor ruled the direct government, during his reign when there were peasant's uprisings in many places, he acted the political role by issuing Jibatsu Rinji to regulate the Eikyo and Kakitsu Disturbances.

Since then, the Emperor ruled the direct government for about thirty years, during his reign when there were peasant uprisings in many places, he acted in a political role by issuing Jibatsu Rinji (an official document of punishment issued by the Emperor) to regulate the Eikyo and Kakitsu Disturbances.
sen.cmt: for about thirty years 補足しました。「治罰綸旨」の英語の説明を加えました。治罰綸旨→定訳不明

sen.j: 1439年に勅撰和歌集（二十一代集）の最後にあたる新続古今和歌集が成立。
sen.e: In 1439 the edition of Shin Shoku Kokin Waka Shu was completed, which was the last edition of Chokusen Waka Shu. (twenty one volumes)
In 1439 the edition of Shin Shoku Kokin Waka Shu was completed, which was the last edition of Chokusen Waka Shu. (twenty one volumes)
In 1439 the edition of Shin Shoku Kokin Waka Shu was completed, which was the last edition of Chokusen Waka Shu. (twenty one volumes)

sen.j: 43年には後南朝勢力が土御門内裏に夜襲をかけ、後花園は逃れるが、三種の神器の一部を奪われる禁闕の変が起こる。
sen.e: In 1443, the ex-Southern Dynasty forces made a night attack to the Tsuchimikado Palace and Emperor Gohanazono escaped, there was the Kinketsu Disturbance occurred and one of three sacred emblems of the Imperial Family was stolen.
sen.cmt: 禁闕の変→the Kinketsu Disturbance[定訳不明]
sen.e: In 1443, the ex-Southern Dynasty forces made a night attack on the Tsuchimikado Palace and Emperor Gohanazono escaped, then the Kinketsu Disturbance occurred and one of three sacred emblems of the Imperial Family was stolen.

In 1443, the Second Southern Court forces made a night attack on the Tsuchimikado Palace and Emperor Gohanazono escaped, then the Kinketsu Disturbance occurred and one of three sacred emblems of the Imperial Family was stolen.

sen.j: 奪われた神器のうち、剣は清水寺で発見されるが、神璽（曲玉）は持ち去られた。
sen.e: The stolen sword was found in Kiyomizu-Dera Temple, however the scared jewel (Shinji, Magatama) was taken away by someone.
sen.cmt: 神璽（曲玉）→a sacred jewel[しんじ（まがたま）]
sen.e: A stolen sword was found in Kiyomizu-Dera Temple, however the scared jewel (Shinji, Magatama) was taken away by someone.
A stolen sword was found in Kiyomizu-dera Temple, however the scared jewel (Shinji, Magatama) was taken away by someone.

sen.j: 1455年、大覚寺統の嫡流である木寺宮に親王宣下して復興。
sen.e: In 1455 the Emperor gave Shinno senge (to title Prince by Imperial order) to the direct line of the Imperial descent, Kidera no Miya for the reconstruction.
In 1455 the Emperor gave Shinno senge (title Prince by Imperial order) to the direct line of Imperial descent, Kidera no Miya for the purpose of reconstruction.
In 1455 the Emperor gave Shinno senge (title Prince by Imperial order) to the direct line of Imperial descent, Kidera no Miya for the purpose of reconstruction.

sen.j: 1457年（長禄元年）には、嘉吉の乱で没落した赤松氏の遺臣が長禄の変で神璽（勾玉）を奪い返し後南朝を殲滅する奮闘をしたので、翌年には三種の神器は北朝の手中に揃っている。
sen.e: In 1457 after the Choroku Incident happened when AKAMATSU family's remained aides, who lost the battle of the Eikyo Disturbance, took away the sacred jewel (Shinji, Magatama) and fought against the ex-Southern Dynasty to exterminate them, on the following year the three sacred jewel was handed to the Northern Dynasty.
sen.cmt: 長禄の変→the Choroku Incident[定訳不明]
sen.e: In 1457 after the Choroku Incident occurred when AKAMATSU family's remaining aides, who lost in battle during the Eikyo Disturbance, took away the sacred jewel (Shinji, Magatama) and fought against the ex-Southern Dynasty to exterminate them, during the following year the three sacred jewels were handed over to the Northern Dynasty.
sen.cmt: revised grammar for clarity and readability
sen.e: In 1457 after the Choroku Incident occurred when Akamatsu clan's remaining aides, who lost in battle during the Kakitsu War, took away the sacred jewel (Shinji, Magatama) and fought against the Second Southern Court to exterminate them, during the following year the three sacred jewels were handed over to the Northern Court.
sen.cmt: 名字小文字にEikyo Disturbance→Kakitsu Warex-Southern Dynasty修正Dynasty→Court"family's"→"clan's"に変更しました。

sen.j: 1461年には常盤井宮に親王宣下を与えて大覚寺統の正統を保存した。
sen.e: In 1461 whe Emperor gave Shino senge (to title Prince by Imperial order) to Tokiwai no Miya to keep the legitimate Daikaku-ji Imperial line.
In 1461the Emperor gave Shino senge (title Prince by Imperial order) to Tokiwai no Miya to maintain the legitimate Daikaku-ji Imperial line.
In 1461the Emperor gave Shino senge (title Prince by Imperial order) to Tokiwai no Miya to maintain the legitimate Daikaku-ji Imperial line.

sen.j: 1464年8月21日に後土御門天皇に譲位して上皇となり、院政を続けた。
sen.e: On August 21st, 1464 he passed the throne to Emperor Gotsuchimikado and became a retired Emperor, he started ruling the cloister government.
On August 21st, 1464 he passed the throne to Emperor Gotsuchimikado and became a retired Emperor, and then he started ruling the cloister government.
On August 21, 1464 he passed the throne to Emperor Gotsuchimikado and became a retired emperor, and then he started ruling the cloister government.

sen.j: 67年から京都で応仁の乱が起こると、後土御門天皇とともに室町亭へ逃れる。
sen.e: In 1467 when the Onin War occurred in Kyoto, the Emperor escaped to Muromachi Mansion together with Emperor Gotsuchimikado.
In 1467 when the Onin War occurred in Kyoto, the Emperor escaped to Muromachi Mansion together with Emperor Gotsuchimikado.
In 1467 when the Onin War occurred in Kyoto, the Emperor escaped to Muromachi Mansion together with Emperor Gotsuchimikado.

sen.j: 1470年12月27日、室町亭で崩御。
sen.e: He died on December 27th, 1470 in Muromachi Mansion.
He died on December 27th, 1470 in the Muromachi Mansion.
He died on December 27, 1470 in the Muromachi Mansion.

sen.j: 闘鶏や猿楽、松はやしなどを好んだ。
sen.e: He enjoyed cockfighting, Sarugaku and Matsu Hayashi.
He enjoyed cockfighting, Sarugaku and Matsu Hayashi.

He enjoyed cockfighting, Sarugaku (comical mimicry and speech performance during the Heian period) and Matsu Hayashi (a festival held at a temple or shrine, where people prayed for good luck and put a pine tree up).
sen.cmt: 「猿楽」、「松はやし」の英語の説明を加えました。

sen.j: 長禄・寛正の飢饉に際しては、将軍足利義政に対して、漢詩を以って諌めたとするエピソードもある。
sen.e: There was an episode that the Emperor sent a Chinese poem to Shogun, Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA to admonish him when Choroku, Kansho Famine occurred.
There was an episode where the Emperor sent a Chinese poem to Shogun, Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA to admonish him when the Choroku, Kansho Famine occurred.
There was an episode where the Emperor sent a Chinese poem to Shogun, Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA to admonish him when the Choroku, Kansho Famine occurred.

tit.e: The poem made by the Emperor
The poem written by the Emperor
The poem written by the Emperor

sen.j: 思へただ空にひとつの日の本に又たぐひなく生まれ来し身を
sen.e: I think about my own special destiny where I was born, just like there is only one sun shinning in the sky.
I think about my own special destiny where I was born, just like there is only one sun shinning in the sky.
I think about my own special destiny where I was born, just like there is only one sun shinning in the sky.
Shocho (July 28, 1428) - September 5, 1429
Shocho (July 28, 1428) - September 5, 1429
Shocho (July 28, 1428) - September 5, 1429
Eikyo September 5, 1429 - February 17, 1441
Eikyo September 5, 1429 - February 17, 1441
Eikyo September 5, 1429 - February 17, 1441
Kakitsu February 17, 1441 - February 5, 1444
Kakitsu February 17, 1441 - February 5, 1444
Kakitsu February 17, 1441 - February 5, 1444
Bun-an February 5, 1444 - July 28, 1449
Bun-an February 5, 1444 - July 28, 1449
Bun-an February 5, 1444 - July 28, 1449
Hotoku July 28, 1449 - July 25, 1452
Hotoku July 28, 1449 - July 25, 1452
Hotoku July 28, 1449 - July 25, 1452
Kyotoku July 25, 1452 - July 25, 1455
Kyotoku July 25, 1452 - July 25, 1455
Kyotoku July 25, 1452 - July 25, 1455
Kosho July 25, 1455 - September 28, 1457
Kosho July 25, 1455 - September 28, 1457
Kosho July 25, 1455 - September 28, 1457
Choroku September 28, 1457 - December 21, 1460
Choroku September 28, 1457 - December 21, 1460
Choroku September 28, 1457 - December 21, 1460
Kansho December 21, 1460 - (July 19, 1464)
Kansho December 21, 1460 - (July 19, 1464)
Kansho December 21, 1460 - (July 19, 1464)

sen.j: 京都府京都市右京区京北井戸町の後山国陵（のちのやまくにのみささぎ）に葬られ、遺骨の一部は、京都市上京区の般舟院陵（はんしゅういんのみささぎ）に分骨された。
sen.e: The Emperor was entombed in Nochi no Yamakuni no Misasagi at Keihoku Ido-cho Town, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, a part of his remain was kept is Hanshuin no Misasagi in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.

The Emperor was entombed in Nochi no Yamakuni no Misasagi at Keihoku Ido-cho Town, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, and part of his remains were kept in Hanshuin no Misasagi in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.

The Emperor was entombed in Nochi no Yamakuni no Misasagi at Keihoku Ido-cho, Ukyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, and part of his remains were kept in Hanshuin no Misasagi in Kamigyo Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 尚、同区に現存する後花園天皇の火葬塚は、京都府内における近世以前の皇室の陵墓・火葬塚の中で、学術上最も確実なものの一つであるといわれる。
sen.e: It is called Emperor Gohanazono's cremated mound which exist in the same Ward has one of the most assuredness in the study of the Imperial Mausoleums and the cremated mound in Kyoto Prefecture during early modern ages.

It is called Emperor Gohanazono's cremation mound and exists in the same Ward has one of the most assuredness in the study of the Imperial Mausoleums and the cremated mound in Kyoto Prefecture during early modern ages.
sen.cmt: the meaning of "has one of the most assuredness" is not understood here. clarification is needed. Also, what is a "cremation mound" (where he was cremated?) and what is the relationship to "the cremated mound in Kyoto Prefecture during early modern ages."?
sen.e: It is called Emperor Gohanazono's cremation mound (a burial mound wherer cremated remains are stored) and it exists in the same Ward, this cremation mound is known for the most accurate historical information in the study of the Imperial Mausoleums and cremation mounds of the early modern ages that exist in Kyoto Prefecture.
sen.cmt: ネイティブチェッカーのコメント通りに修正しました。aciculate→accuratecreated→cremation
